article_title: Vet recalls unusual experiences in Vietnam (videos added)
article_text:
Kenneth Seifert saw two rare animals in mountains of wartorn country

Click through this slideshow of each video we've done to represent our Vietnam veterans in this series.

Kenneth Seifert didn't talk about his service in Vietnam for a long time, but it wasn't because of his nightmares or a painful homecoming. It was because no one believed the incredible stories he told.

Seifert lived in Nokomis, Ill. and volunteered for the Air Force at age 19 right before he was sent a letter to be drafted. He was in Vietnam from 1969 to 1970.

He volunteered for Vietnam because the government had a rule that only one family member could be sent to any one combat. His brother was in the Air Force and had a wife and child. "I was still single and crazy," Seifert said.

He was with the military police and performed a variety of tasks in Vietnam. He delivered guns to a nomad group in the Vietnamese mountains called the Montagnard, pronounced mountain yard or "mountain people."

He saw two rare animals, a deer that barked like a dog, and a rabbit with stripes like a zebra. The chief of the tribe heard this story and decided to shoot a monkey to roast as a celebration of this rare sighting.

The arrow he shot with a crossbow was tipped with a sleeping substance. It arced through the air, hit a branch instead of the monkey, and whirled around to hit Seifert in the leg.

Seifert said that in 1999, he saw a newspaper article about some new animals discovered in Vietnam. Among these were a barking deer and an Annamite striped rabbit.

Seifert also used to bring candy and make slingshots for the children in those nomad tribes.

Advertisement

One of those boys was later adopted and brought to America. That boy recognized Seifert in a Walmart several years ago and said, "You made me a slingshot!"

Seifert was transferred to another unit, he said, and spent nine months there, when the life expectancy in that area was 90 days.

Seifert was well-aware of how unpopular the war was. "We weren't allowed to finish it," he said. "We could have stood arm to arm and walked the whole country and eradicated it. But that wasn't the intent."

The military built the infrastructure of South Vietnam with highways and military bases. And then they left and gave the people whatever they had. "And where did it end up? In the hands of the North Vietnamese, anyway," Seifert said.

When he got off the plane on his return in Seattle, Wash., he remembers seeing a group of bald monks. They saw he had a uniform on and they spat at him.

"As a military policeman, I smiled with a curious smile back at them and I told them, 'If you only knew, you wouldn't be spitting,'" he said. Seifert and the other men went inside to change. He said that his fellow soldiers wanted "to do something."

Seifert told them, "The best thing to do is to let them learn the lesson the long way. Sometimes they won't listen. They won't learn until it hits them in the face."

His family in Illinois welcomed him back with open arms because he had come back alive. He met his wife, Lynda, in 1972 in Cheyenne, Wyo., and they eventually settled in Colorado because they loved the mountains.

Note from the Editor: This is the second in a series of weekly articles on Vietnam veteran homecomings. Veterans Day is Nov. 11 and the theme this year is a welcome home to Vietnam vets. Look for feature stories on Vietnam veterans every Monday through Nov. 11. Veterans who have stories to share can call 669-5050 ext. 530. Community members are invited to thank Vietnam veterans for their service at 599-1218.

From everyone at the Reporter-Herald to veterans who have served: Thank you for your service and welcome home.

Jessica Benes can be reached at 669-5050, ext. 530, or jbenes@reporter-herald.com. Follow her on Twitter: @JessicaBenes. Read her blog at jessicabenes.com.
